reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “rapid reconfiguration” move (via Jones-style long-run substitution) as a key support for expecting higher effective substitutability (ρ closer to 0) in AI R&D than in standard economic estimates. This is relevant but not load-bearing for the overall position, since the paper offers multiple independent reasons (e.g., algorithmic efficiency enabling more experiments, non-frontier experimentation/extrapolation, alternate routes not requiring compute-heavy experiments). Hence centrality is moderate-low. The critique has moderate strength: it plausibly highlights an under-argued step (why organizational/process innovation wouldn’t itself be compute/experiment bottlenecked), which weakens that specific rebuttal, but it doesn’t show a strict circularity or refute other pathways to higher ρ. Most claims are correct and conceptually coherent, though “assuming the conclusion” is somewhat overstated because the paper could be read as hypothesizing, not presupposing, fast reconfiguration. It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Reconfiguration assumes substitutability to prove substitutability
